content: It’s not just a conference—it's a movement. Proud to be part of this community.
More accessibility features would help ensure everyone can fully enjoy what EuroPython has to offer. It's a great community to be inclusive for all.
The sprint sessions were incredibly productive—I contributed to a library I use daily and learned a ton in the process.
EuroPython’s code of conduct enforcement sets a high standard. Felt safe and respected.
Python core devs being accessible made this feel like a once-in-a-lifetime experience.
Great diversity of speakers this year. Felt very inclusive and well-represented.
The sprints were one of the highlights for me—I got to work alongside developers I’ve only ever read about online!
The WiFi held up surprisingly well given the number of people and devices connected—massive credit to the IT crew!
The food options were top-notch, especially for vegetarians and vegans. Finally, a conference that doesn't forget us!
It was a bit expensive compared to other conferences, but the quality and value definitely justified the cost.
The schedule was packed—I barely had time to breathe, but it was worth it!
The hallway track was better than most main stages elsewhere. Some of the most valuable learning moments came from spontaneous conversations.
The sticker collection alone was worth the trip. My laptop now looks like a Python shrine—and I wouldn’t have it any other way.
I’m walking away with so many ideas to bring back to my team. Definitely worth the investment of time and money.
The t-shirts were ugly, but I wore mine proudly anyway. Inside joke material!
The t-shirts were ugly, but I wore mine proudly anyway. Inside joke material!
EuroPython is where introverts become extroverts. Met so many new friends!
Python core devs being accessible made this feel like a once-in-a-lifetime experience.
The open spaces were a nice touch. Got to talk about real-world use cases with fellow devs.
EuroPython gets better every year. I’ve already booked my flight for next summer—no hesitation!
The mobile app was useful for planning, though it crashed a couple of times. Nothing major, but room for improvement.
Would love to see more interactive workshops rather than just lectures.
EuroPython keeps getting better each year. Already looking forward to next time!
A few talks leaned too heavily on theory without enough practical examples. More real-world use cases would help bridge the gap.
There’s something magical about being surrounded by hundreds of Python enthusiasts—you can feel the passion in the air.
It would be great to see more interactive workshops where you actually write code instead of just watching someone else do it.
The coffee was bad, but the code was good. A fair trade-off!
It was a bit expensive compared to other conferences, but the quality and value definitely justified the cost.
It would be great to see more interactive workshops where you actually write code instead of just watching someone else do it.
The open spaces were a nice touch. Got to talk about real-world use cases with fellow devs.
Some of the best discussions happened outside the official program—in hallways, during meals, and at evening events.
Sponsor booths were nice, but I found myself skipping most of them after realizing they didn’t offer much beyond t-shirts and stickers.
This conference recharged my professional batteries and reminded me why I love working with Python and its community.
EuroPython should do a virtual option too. Not everyone can travel easily.
The organization was flawless this year. I especially loved the beginner-friendly workshops!
What I love about EuroPython is that it’s not just about writing code—it’s about building a better tech world together.
There’s something magical about being surrounded by hundreds of Python enthusiasts—you can feel the passion in the air.
I didn't realize how much I missed in-person events until this one. Worth every minute.
They need more gender-neutral restrooms next time. It’s a small change that makes a big difference in inclusion efforts.
It was great to see so many underrepresented voices on stage—this conference really sets a high standard for inclusivity.
Kudos to the organizers for including mental health awareness and quiet zones—small touches that made a big difference.
They need more gender-neutral bathrooms next time. Important step toward inclusivity.
The mobile app was useful for planning, though it crashed a couple of times. Nothing major, but room for improvement.
Some talks went too deep into niche topics. Would prefer more general Python content.
As always, EuroPython delivered an incredible atmosphere, but I did wish there was more time between sessions for reflection or networking.
EuroPython is where introverts become extroverts. Met so many new friends!
I came here feeling burnt out, and left energized. That’s no small feat. Thank you to everyone involved!
EuroPython is the kind of event that turns introverts into extroverts. I met so many awesome people and even made a few lifelong friends.
EuroPython isn’t just a conference; it’s a movement. Being part of this community feels like being part of something bigger.
More accessibility features would help ensure everyone can fully enjoy what EuroPython has to offer. It's a great community to be inclusive for all.
The networking lounges were chill and helped meet people without pressure.
The schedule was packed—I barely had time to breathe, but it was worth it!
This year’s EuroPython felt like a perfect blend of technical depth and community spirit, and I made some great connections that I know will last beyond the event.
The networking lounges were chill and helped meet people without pressure.
Venue was a bit small this time, felt crowded during lunch hours.
I came here feeling burnt out, and left energized. That’s no small feat. Thank you to everyone involved!
EuroPython showed me that the Python community is full of passionate, smart, and caring individuals. That’s rare and precious.
I’d love to see more hands-on tutorials next time. Lectures are great, but doing things together helps reinforce learning.
The educational track was inspiring—especially the sessions on teaching coding to kids and non-traditional learners.
EuroPython is more than a conference—it's a celebration of curiosity and collaboration.
A few talks leaned too heavily on theory without enough practical examples. More real-world use cases would help bridge the gap.
EuroPython gets better every year. I’ve already booked my flight for next summer—no hesitation!
EuroPython was absolutely inspiring! The keynotes were top-notch and the community vibe is unbeatable.
Great diversity of speakers this year. Felt very inclusive and well-represented.
Venue was a bit small this time, felt crowded during lunch hours.
The volunteers were outstanding—they handled everything with grace and kept things running smoothly throughout the week.
EuroPython isn’t just a conference; it’s a movement. Being part of this community feels like being part of something bigger.
EuroPython continues to be the highlight of my summer every year. Great job everyone!
A bit pricey compared to other conferences, but the value was definitely there.
The app for scheduling talks crashed a few times, but overall still helpful.
EuroPython should consider rotating host cities more often. New places bring fresh energy!
I came here feeling burnt out, and left energized. That’s no small feat. Thank you to everyone involved!
The venue was amazing and the talks were packed with insights I hadn’t considered before.
The hallway track was gold. Some of the best conversations happened outside sessions.

This conference recharged my career batteries. Thanks to everyone involved!

This conference recharged my professional batteries and reminded me why I love working with Python and its community.
I’m walking away with so many ideas to bring back to my team. Definitely worth the investment of time and money.
It’s not just a conference—it's a movement. Proud to be part of this community.
The post-event survey arrived too late. It would be better to send it while memories are still fresh and accurate.
The PyCon sprint was amazing. Learned so much working side by side with others.
The organization was flawless this year. I especially loved the beginner-friendly workshops!
It would be great to see more interactive workshops where you actually write code instead of just watching someone else do it.
EuroPython should consider rotating cities more frequently—it brings fresh perspectives and keeps the energy alive.
The mobile app was useful for planning, though it crashed a couple of times. Nothing major, but room for improvement.
I’d love to see more hands-on tutorials next time. Lectures are great, but doing things together helps reinforce learning.
Some of the beginner sessions could have gone into more detail, but overall it was a solid experience.
EuroPython is where introverts become extroverts. Met so many new friends!
EuroPython is more than just a conference—it’s a vibrant celebration of curiosity, collaboration, and creativity within the Python world.
The app for scheduling talks crashed a few times, but overall still helpful.
So happy they included mental health resources and quiet zones this year.
This conference recharged my career batteries. Thanks to everyone involved!
I wish there were more hands-on tutorials for specific libraries like NumPy or Pandas.
Too many parallel tracks made it hard to choose. Maybe next time they could offer recordings right away?
The coffee wasn’t great, but the code was. I guess we can forgive a few small flaws when everything else is so well done.
The volunteer team deserves a standing ovation—they handled everything smoothly.
The t-shirts were ugly, but I wore mine proudly anyway. Inside joke material!
It was a bit expensive compared to other conferences, but the quality and value definitely justified the cost.
